ReviewList.Text: In my experience, biographies of great scientists often leave the reader in a fog of technical complexity.  While this book is not "Physics in One Simple Lesson," Walter Isaacson did a wonderful job of telling the story of the man and making the scientific aspects sufficiently understandable to be useful in grasping the magnitude of Einstein's intellect.  This book is meticulously researched and sourced, yet written in a witty and entertaining way that makes reading it a pleasure.  The central lesson that I was left with was the importance of independent thinking in any context.  Einstein made it clear that conventional wisdom is often neither practical, nor wise.  I was struck by his resiliance in his early years and his good humor in really tough times.  I also appreciated the fact that the author was willing to examine all aspects of Eintein's personality, both favorable and unfavorable.

With the 2006 release of the massive personal papers of Albert Einstein, the door was finally opened to the last remaining secrets of the life of the most renowned mathematician, scientist and quantum physicist of the 20th Century. By covering in great detail Einstein's entire life from his 1879 German childbirth to his passing from a bursting aneurysm in 1955 at age 76, Issacson has created a much broader understanding of the man, his pursuits and the often turbulent times in which he lived. Facing great dissent (including that of the anti-Semites) in the pre-war Germany of the 20's and 30's, the controversial and publicity seeking scientist is revealed to relish his often contrarian view of science, politics and society while at the same time becoming celebrated by the famous and politically powerful far beyond his country's borders. Einstein's motivations, dedication, creative phases and ultimate fame are all revealed in a finely detailed, cogent yet highly readable presentation that gives a new appreciation of the persona behind the discoveries of relativity, the expanding universe and unified theories. Beyond pure science, Isaacson explores his dedication to family, society and cultural Zionism which in 1932, just before Hilter's assent to Chancellor, ultimately lead to his relocation to Princeton University and the United States. Having covered such weighty literary ground as his recent biographies of big-thinkers like Benjamin Franklin and Henry Kissinger, the former CNN chairman and Time magazine managing editor (where in 1999, Einstein was named 'Person of the Century') continues to build his case for being in a lofty league of serious contemporary authors in his own rite.

I am 75 years old and have read over a dozen books on Einstein and his work, including his own. This is the best book ever on the personal life and tribulations of a great scientist as he trys to get his work done. With all the flaws and worts of a human the scientist struggles on.

If you have any interest or curiosity of Einstein's life and work, this book is for you.  Absolutely a first rate expose of Einstein the man. I was thrilled to learn about his nature and character. Isaacson did a fabulous job in weaving together all the extraneous events and people that were part of Einstein's life both personal and professional. Einstein was a real person, with emotion, humor, true character and conviction. He developed his beliefs from his direct experience and stuck to them. I only wish I had had the opportunity to meet him. But through Isaacson's book I feel as though I have.  Enjoy.  5 stars+.

I thought Isaacson's Benjamin Franklin may have been the best biography I've ever read, so I couldn't have been more excited when I saw he'd written a biography on Einstein.  I think Isaacson's made an incredible effort here, but whereas you really felt he knew the guy in the Franklin book, it almost feels that with Einstein he's trying his hardest to be an "insider" in a crowd he really doesn't fit in with (for better or worse).  Consequently, he endlessly falls back to some very sweeping themes like "Einstein always believed in independent thinking" without really being able to articulate the nuances of those ideas in the context of a scientist.  He wants to have the comfort with Einsteing that he successfully built with the story of Franklin, but he never quite gets there.  There's some great information here...and I'll continue to excitedly look forward to Isaacson's future work; but I think the biography may have been better served by scientist who learned to write rather than a writer who tried to learn science.

Einstein's life is portrayed with love, humor, respect, and a desire to show more than just the facts about this brilliant man. This biography offers insight into not only Einstein's contribution to math and physics, but also his contribution to our understanding of God and the possibility of intelligent design. I appreciated the even-handed description of Einstein's own inability to reconcile his perception of the deep mystery of natural law with the mathematical proofs he developed to prove quantum theory. I have very limited science and math background and was lost in some of the more technical explanations (scientists will love these parts) but it didn't bother me and I skipped these few places that befuddled my unscientific mind. Those who are interested in how quantum physics informs spiritual belief and practice will appreciate this book. I loved the quote from one of Einstein's friends who told him to "stop telling God what to do." As a Jewish reader, I appreciated the insight about his relationship to his people, his faith, the State of Israel, and the tradition of promoting social justice so much a part of the Jewish culture in which I was raised. This book is very thought-provoking and has led me into some interesting discussions with others about the nature of reality and the purpose of us mere mortals.

Isaacson has writen a thorough, pleasant and even-handed biography of an extremely difficult subject and therefore deserves something of a pass because it is very likely impossible for a biographer to do justice to every aspect of a life like Einstein's. In the same way that Einstein fell short of a true unified theory (or so we think) the writer ultimately fails to bring together the myriad wavelengths of the inventor of e=mc(squared). While Isaacson is reasonably successful at explaining the Theory of Relativity to non-physicists he falls down when trying probe the depths of Einstein's motivations and decisions, especially later in life when the author treats his subject like a kindly, old, semi-deranged misanthrope. I also found his snide digs at other biographers unhelpful. Moreover, it is extremely hard to accept this biographer's contention that Einstein had completely lost his way in the study of Space and Time and spent the last 30 years of his life playing with inconsequential equations. The strongest parts of the book deal with Einstein's politics and roots of his pacifism. Perhaps Einstein needs a physicist to write a more respectful, thoughtful book about his life and work as a physicist.

Isaacson's new biography of Einstein describes him as a person in the context of family, history, relationships, and thought.  It presents Einstein as a living, breathing, thinking human being.  I was fascinated by the book and am now quite fascinated with Einstein.  I must admit I had to read the Theory of Relativity six or seven times before I somewhat understood it.

Walter Isaacson has written a masterpiece of a autobigraphy on the great genuis. You come away with a feeling of actually knowing Einstein personally and your life is better for it. I do not even feign to understand the science of Einstein which Isaacson delivers in manner which never belittles you but it is there for greater minds then mine to fully understand. But this book is about the rebellious loner who scorned authority and conventional thinking and changed the course of human existence with his wandering curiosity. A man who was so humble in his greatness and believed in "A spirit is manifest in the laws of the universe-a spirit vastly superior to that of man,and one in the face of which we with our modest powers must feel humble". Isaacson also does away with the false legends of Einstein, who did not fail math and who was much more proficient at math then it is believed though he himself would always chastise his lack of mathmatical skills. He also does not come across as an atheist but a man more in touch with wonder and awe of a spirit in the universe which always left him in awe. This led him to postulate and wonder of the mysteries of the universe which led him to never abandon his deepy-held belief that there was an order to it all which rightly or wrongly held him back from firmly believing in quantum physics. Einstein used to say, "When I am judging a theory, I ask myself wheter, if I were God, I would have arranged the world in such a way." We can only imagine the great conversations between God and His prized pupil.

I purchased the Albert Einstein biography by Walter Isaacson because I had recently finished the bio of Steve Jobs by the same author.  Mr. Isaacson captures everything about people, places and situations so eloquently in words (and probably accurately--how would I know?) that it's hard to realize he wasn't in the same room when life happened for all the ones he writes about.  His ability to write about the technical aspects of Apple, and the computer business in general, is amazing, and I find, as I'm reading about Albert Einstein, Mr. Isaacson has the same abilty to make me think he studied physics alongside of Einstein, or at the very least was a friend of his.  I love the way he portrays the characters.  It's much like reading a novel, but the story is true!

A wonderful book which gives full and equal weight to both the man and the ideas which made him great, as well as the lasting place of those ideas in the history of scientific thought, if not of human thought itself.  And on that latter point, the reader's debt to Isaacson is undoubtedly primarily for his continuing emphasis on Einstein's modus operandi: thought experiments, by which through the exercise merely of pure thought and a perspective unhampered by received wisdoms, a man was able to change millennia-old views of how we viewed the universe, and by extension, changed the universe itself.  Whose thinking could remain uninfluenced by such a display of the power of thought?

I bought this book because I thought it might help me better understand the special and general theories of relativity by allowing me, as it were, to follow in Einstein's footsteps while he developed them. It did that; my understanding of them, while still shaky, is much better than it was. But the really exciting aspect of this story turned out to be the incredible difficulty which even geniuses ( to say nothing of the rest of us ) have in struggling and overcoming our inherited ways of thinking. Max Planck refused to accept the full implications of his epochal equation E=h x f for decades, and then, very ironically, Einstein, who saw Planck's problem so clearly,  had the same problem when he got older. Although his Nobel-Prize winning 1905 paper on the photoelectric effect unquestionably makes him one of the founding fathers of quantum physics, he simply could not shake off his visceral conviction that "real" physics makes deterministic rather than statistical or probabilistic predictions. How ironic that the man who superseded Newton's law of universal gravitation was a deterministic arch-Newtonian at heart ! And what a lesson in humility and skepticism toward the contents of our brains to the rest of us !

I enjoyed reading this biography of Dr. Albert Einstein, based, in part, on his personal correspondence over the decades of the first half of the 20th century.  In this manner, the reader gets to know him as a person as well as the meaning of his scientific endeavors.  His colleagues were a Who's Who of modern physics, chemistry, and mathematics.  Isaacson also explores his pacifism/activism in addition to his personal relationships and cult of celebrity.  If you always wondered what the theory of relativity was all about, then this is the book for you.

Einstein was a great read - I gained a new appreciation for Einstein as a person and his scientific world. In the beginning of the book, I didn't know quite what to think of Einstein. I couldn't tell if he possessed great confidence or if he crossed over to being arrogant, and I wasn't impressed with how he handled his personal relationships. However, as the book went on, I gained an appreciation for his thirst for knowledge, his independent thinking, confidence, determination, and even kindness

Who was Albert Einstein and what made him tick? Getting inside the mind of Albert Einstein beyond his scientific accomplishments is accomplished for the reader by author Walter Isaacson. Isaacson gives the reader a portrait of a uniquely curious, fascinating, and passionate man with high ideals for himself and humanity who was also detached at times at the expense of those close to him, fiercely independent, and marched to his own drummer even at personal and professional cost. Reading about Einstein making his way through society and his times were the most interesting part of this book for me. Besides his life as a thoretical physicist, Einstein was an active participant (on his own terms of course) and observer of the world around him as he strived to live a virtuous (my words, not his) life. Isaacson tells Einstein's life is told in the context of his times including the Europe around the turn of the 20th century, World War I, the rise of Communism and Nazism, World War II, the founding of the State of Israel, and McCarthyism.  No matter what the era, place, or ideology, Einstein tended to gently push the envelope of convention. He enjoyed his fame, but did not give in to his principles to obtain and keep it by going along with the wishes of governments, his scientific colleagues, and the prevailing political correctness. Einstein was very spiritual in his own way and spoke of God as "the old one" and believed the universe and its natural laws to be the product of some sort of divine design. His God was generally and impersonal God in the Deist sense.  Nevertheless, Einstein saw a divine presence in the laws of nature and his search for a "Unified" theory was partly based on how he thought God would set up the universe and its natural laws.  Although Isaacson concentrates on Einstein the man, he does not skimp on his scientific development, methods, and accomplishments. The book contains lengthy descriptions of Einstein's theories that sometimes became too complex and confusing for a generally scientific and mathematical illiterate such as me. Nevertheless, I did learn a lot and am glad to have been challenged and always had the option of skipping ahead. I am now reading Isaacson's biography of Benjamin Franklin. Although more different than alike, both men had a curiosity and sense of wonder that makes one realize why Isaacson dovetailed into a biography of Albert Einstein.

Wonderfully informative and unbiased account. I didn't give it five stars because I thought the writing was a bit flat; but,nonetheless, I breezed through it and didn't get confused by the physics; in fact, Isaacson did a pretty good job of defining "it all".

Walter Isaacson does a remarkable job of writing about Einstein in a compelling and elegant way.  Both the author and subject are equally interesting.  I work as a Life Coach and Business Coach and quote both Einstein and Isaacson regularly.  This is a must read and a real literary delight.

Throughout my career in neurology, I had been somewhat confused about Einstein's unbelief in a God, but Isaacson clarifies that the eminent genius was indeed atheistic if not agnostic. Convincing quotes from Einstein in Isaacson's book: "A foolish faith in authority is the greatest enemy of truth" and "I am a deeply religious nonbeliever...a somewhat new kind of religion". But foremost by Einstein: "Through reading popular scientific books, I soon reached the conviction that much in...the Bible could not be true. The consequence was a positively frantic orgy of freethinking coupled with the impression that youth is intentionally being deceived by the state through lies; it was a crushing impression". Yet like Gibran, Einstein was impressed by nature's laws inclusive of humans: "Science w/o religion [passion] is lame; religion w/o science is blind..."

I have read many Einstein biographies and find this among the best.The author does an excellent job, giving us a window into some of Einstein's personal and professional trials and triumphs.Thoroughly enjoyable.

The book was well written in that it focused on enough detail to tie the different events of his life together and at the same time takes us on tangents through 'thought experiments', emotion and logic driven thoughts, failed relationships, etc.  The book represents Einstein as a human with a strong focus on the characteristics that were behind his greatness, namely curiousity and a drive to bring structure where there was none. This book allow me to examine my own life and strategies through my own 'thought experiments' and that is the best you can say about any book (or relationship for that matter).

It must be difficult to write about a man who died a long time ago and to only rely on references to what others have already written. That is how this book appears to me: a collection of quotes painfully pulled from the literature, stitched together by unexciting prose. I read this Isaacson book with great expectations after I read his Steve Jobs biography. But I was disappointed. Isaacson also repeats himself frequently, to the point of verbatim repeat sentences. This is odd, today's editing technology should catch that or he uses this intentionally as filler (his books are unnecessarily long).

Very good book. Still reading it. I like especially the fact that it talks a lot about actual physics and puts in place many important events and discoveries. I wish I knew all that stuff when I was learning the theory in school - especially the history of the particle-wave dualism of the light. It makes it all closer and you can almost feel all the tensions (or lack thereof) in the world of physics at that time. Many thoughts experiments made by Einstein are nicely presented.

A very interesting biography for non-physicists like me who would like to better understand relativity, if at all possible...  Einstein's genial theories are explained within their historical context, and the author provides extensive and pertinent biographical detail.  It is most readable, and I recommend it highly to anyone interested in understanding new ideas in the twentieth century.

Isaacson did another excellent job of covering the life of one of the 20th century's most fascinating people. He captured the excitement of the early physics year between 1900 and 1925 as well as the long struggle with unification of all forces. His insights into his complex personality and family life were fascinating as was his strong opposition to nationalism and fascism. A great read.

Issacson is one of the best biographers working today, his Benjamin Franklin was a masterpiece and this time he has equaled that effort. Albert Einstein comes alive as a real human being, wiping away some of the foolish myths that have followed his legend. He is seen in his domestic life even as he works on some of his greatest accomplishments, and in humanizing him Isasson exposes how truly special a person Einstein was.

This book was an interesting and informative history of Einstein.  I enjoyed reading every page and was astonished at the amount of research and information provided.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it as a story and was impressed with the treatment of the personal aspects of his life

This is an enjoyable book to read, well-written with a smooth flow. Its main claim to fame, considering the many biographies of Al that have already been printed and sold, is that it reveals the newly uncensored letters and other material that the public was prevented from seeing. In short, it describes some of the 'dirt' that Al's friends and literary editors have concealed from the public. His coldness and mean-spirited treatment of his children reveal his almost reptilian affect where family relationships were involved.  For example, when he got his girlfriend pregnant and she gave birth to his illegitimate daughter, he refused to visit her or to even see his newborn baby. Instead, realizing that an illegitimate child would certainly damage his career potential, he gave orders to dump the baby into an orphanage. Much of the correspondence regarding this matter between Al and his girlfriend has been destroyed by the families. He pursued a similar coldness toward his legitimate son Eduard who was schizophrenic. He just refused to visit or see him and emotionally abandoned the child. I will say in Al's defense that he did provide financially for Eduard's upkeep in a mental institution in Switzerland. It is the revelation of the details of Al's personal life that make this book so interesting. It would be nice if even more personal information could be revealed such as the many infidelities with women that took place while he was married. These are hinted at but not described. The book has one annoying flaw which continues to irritate page after page. The author insists on using that pigeon-English expression "thought experiment" over and over again. The use of this ugly phrase seems to be required of Al's biographers as if de rigeur. It should be discarded once and for all. I notice that the index has no mention of Lieserl, Al's daughter. I guess the author also regards her as of no importance. One humorous note - the author claims he learned tensor calculus in order to write the book. Somehow I don't think I will ask for his help the next time I wish to calculate the divergence in spherical coordinates of a contravariant vector.

This was one of our Book Club's selections.  I looked at its size and procrastinated opening it.  But, when I began reading this book, I couldn't put it down.  The author makes his life seem very interesting and the science is put in laymans terms.  I loved this book!

I picked up this book and could not put it down, Walter Isaacson bought Albert Einstein to life for me in the pages of this book. From his struggling beginnings, through his two marriages, the war years and the atomic bomb.  I found out more about the man who bought us into the atomic age and how reluctant he was to do it.  Great summer reading.

The book is quite comprehensive about Einstein's life given that most people who intimately knew Einstein were gone. However, it is curious that the author did not chase down his children and relatives in Europe for their opinions of Einstein.

EXCELLENT.....FIVE STARS PLUS.  I have ready many books about Einstein.  I was reluctant to purchase this one as I thought it would be a rehash.  I was wonderfully surprised.  The historical chapters are well written.  The technical chapters are done equally well.  A big round of applause for the author. I learned quite a bit.
A very well written book with so much details in Eisten's personl life as well as  scientific advance of this great genius. Very enjoyable reading.
It is a very good biography of Einstein. It should be on one's bookshelf along with other Einstein biographies such as the one by Ronald Clark.

You think you know Einstein.  I thought I did, and then I read Isaacson's well-researched, moving, personal depiction of the man.  Sure, there's the stuff everyone knows - relativity, his humble beginnings as a patent clerk, his involvement in (or, as it turns out, his absence from) the Manhattan Project.  What few people may know is that Einstein was in some ways brilliant and prone to wildly amazing insights about nature and physics - but he could also be naive, stubborn, standoffish, unable to maintain relationships with those closest to him... in short, he was incredibly human.  An added strength of this book, beyond the humanistic approach, was the very clear, concise way in which Isaacson described physics concepts that most people find incredibly hard to understand.  Well worth your time, whether you're a physics nut or a biography buff.
This is an excllent work on one of our most interesting humans. This book comfortably tackles a complex topic. Great read.

Walter Isaacson has done a superior job of summarizing and probing the life of Albert Einstein.  Readers will finish this biography with a fair knowledge of Einstein's scientific accomplishments, his religious and political views, as well as his character, personal and social life.  The idiosyncrasy, the rebelliousness and sometimes conservatism (at least vis-à-vis quantum mechanics and the uncertainty principle) are discussed in good detail.  Those not familiar with Einstein's theory relativity in the general or special cases will have ample opportunities, analogies, and examples (many Einstein's own) to make it comprehensible.  Overall this is a well-researched and very well-written book, destined to become a classic on Einstein's mind, life and world.

I finished reading the biography today. I've always looked up to the genius of the man, the book helped clear the aura behind those bushy hair and that phenomenal brain. The chapters on physics and relativity were good, but the ones documenting his fame and his views on religion and the politics of the era (antisemitism, WWII and Germany, McCarthyism in the USA in the early 1950's) were better. As a "religious non-believer" myself, there was a lot I could relate to. One of the most inspiring tales you'll ever come across. I didn't plan to finish reading the book on Einstein's birthday, but I think the coincidence points toward his view of that unknown entity, his version of 'God', which manifests itself in harmony, timing and simplicity in nature.

If anyone out there is similar to me in trying to find ways to utilize the time spent commuting back and forth to work the 18 CD audio version of Einstein is just the ticket.  I am neither an Einstein expert or neophyte but was in fact just interested in expanding on my core knowledge and world/american history.  I can fervently admit I have achieved both having just completed the final CD.  You will no doubt find a number of reviews contained herein debating the pros and cons of this body of work by Isaacson. This collection of CD's is a no-brainer.  Wonderful information intelligently read aloud by Edward Herrmann covering the entire life of one of the world's most enlightened thinkers.  Don't hesitate to purchase it - it is worth every dollar.

My husband and I listened over a very long car trip.  He has a great physics background and I do not.  The story of the man, his times, and people around him is fascinating.  I, however, found the long pieces of theoretical physics very hard going.  Though it would not have been "complete" without them, I was the driver, and happily skipped through until we got to some narrative.  In that way, I was VERY happy with this marvelous book.  We also own the hardcover and my husband can go back over the descriptions of the thought experiments, papers, theories, particles, relativity, and quanta to his hearts content, without me!

I am a huge fan of Einstein and this book has incredible information of the life of this iconic man. The book is extremely long and has its dull moments as expected from Isaacson, but if you can get pass that then this should be a very enlightening biography. This book really goes into detail of Einsteins life and attempts to give the reader an inside feel of how his mind worked. I think this is a great book for anyone who longs for knowledge and is perfectly fine with reading a book of this length, but most importantly enjoys Isaacson's work.

Though my brain is neither wired nor educated  to even remotely understand all the scientific information and discussions imparted in this book, I am fascinated to read the interesting personal life of the great scientist.  He was a fascinating character, so human, so common, and a such a rascal, yet such a gift to the world.  I'm reading at the half-way point and remain delighted with the book.  I highly recommended it even to those who are not scientific "brains."  I appreciated the prompt shipping service, too.

An enlightening look at Einstein's life from birth to death and everythinig inbetween. There was just enough discusion of physics to give you a background, but comprehendable to the non-physists of the world. The author covered the creation of the theory of relativity, but it was not the focus of the book. It rather focused on Einstein's aproach to life, his way of thinking and philosophies that caused him to create his theories. I found the book a comprehensive view of his life and entirely enjoyable.

This book is very detailed and long, covering his life and relationships chronologically.  The book does a good job of discussing his great works, and provides good information to the average reader.  One thing I would have liked more from the book would have been a true study of how his mind worked, and he worked on a daily basis.  A tremendous effort was put into the book by Mr. Isaacson, and it has to be one of the most detailed biographies I ever read.

I don't read a lot of biographies and am not even sure why I picked this one up to delve into. Other reviewers have had lengthy comments on the content, so I'll skip one of my usual lengthy reviews to say it was a well written book that allowed those of the non-scientific ilk to understand the science Einstein based his life on as well as Einstein himself. It flowed together and provided a portrait of a deeply flawed, but passionately driven genius.

This is a very well written and interesting book.  It contains many insights into Einstein's personal life, of which I was hertofore unfamiliar, particularly with regard to his views on religion and God and his family relationships.  There was enough science included (and explained to the point that I could almost follow it) to make the book coherent and provide a tiny glimpse of Einstein's intellect and how he struggled with the complexities of the physical world.

Einstein as written would be a worthy biography had it ended around 1913 with the Nobel prize and the pinnacle of his scientific accomplishment behind him. The story to that point was compelling reading and emotionally satisfying. Unfortunately the pace and my interest flagged after 1932. As a plus the early reading convinced me to buy a physics text and begin study as I'd never taken physics in High School or University.

Even though it's massive, this book is a total page turner, and despite its size and the fact that I'm a full time physics student (or maybe because of that), I felt like I couldn't put it down. Even though I was busy at the time I read it in a matter of weeks. The author truly brings life to Einstein's story, and even though now I know more about his personal faults, I've never admired him more. Fantastic book.

I found this biography interesting. Not fascinating, but interesting. I derived a tiny bit of insight into relativity theory and quantum mechanics. I was mostly interested in the book's description of Einstein's personal and professional life. I agree with some reviewers' complaints that Isaacson was too repetitive in describing Einstein's personality.

I knew very little about Einstein the person and this book does a great job discussing Einstein, the person that we was, his thoughts and beliefs, and of course his works of genius and what drove those. A well balanced book for which Isaacson seems to have done his research well, and has presented his findings equally impressively.

Dry and overladen with textbook matter.  This book understates the life of a hero in our world's history.  It would have been even more dazzling to experience emotional gratification in the literary exposition of such an amazing person a as Einstein.  He deserved better and the reader is entitled to a richer experience as well!

I never had any clue about relativity or anything having to do with physics.  Reading about Einstein and how he came to think about things in general isn't any easier to follow, but it's extremely interesting, so much so that one can get lost in the details about Einstein's life, and you'll find that the time spent reading this book passes quickly.

I read and enjoyed Walter Isaacson's book on Steve Jobs, and was looking for other material he'd written. I am delighted with this book and Isaacson's portrayal of Albert Einstein.  I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was a great read, well balanced and inspiring.  I will savor this, and probably re-read it

Extremely well written.  I chose this book based on the writing style of Isacson's Steve Jobs book.  I have not been dissappointed. While some of the detail can be a bit redundant and tedious, the book is very informative and entertaining.  You will look at the world differently after reading this book.

The book combines insights into Einstein's family sphere, scientific endeavors , and internal life that end up providing an entertaining an insightful view o his life that turns out to be more than the sum of its parts.  A great view into the life of the greatest man of the twentieth century.

I love reading the details of biographies - wanting to learn as much as possible - and I really enjoyed the journey that the author took me on in studying the life, perceptions, philosophies, and personal character of Einstein. Great book - it must be a seminole work on the famous physicist.

It is amazing what access to personal papers can do for a biography. This is more than just a dry recitation of facts about his life and a rehash of his famous equation. This will likely take several sittings to get through but it's worth it if you've ever been curious about Albert Einstein.

One more time everything went perfect well. The price I considered fair, delivered exactly as combined and the book is amazing, so, now its just delight my reading. The detail is: I'm buying from São Paulo/ Brasil. You Americans really know how to do certain things well;

I didn't know alot about Albert Einstein other than probably some half truths.  This book brought him to like.  Issacson is an absolute master of putting such an exciting and rich life together as well as showing the real Einstein, Warts and all. Absolutely enjoyable.

This book is exhaustive in its scope. When you are done reading it you will feel like you knew the man personally. He was not always a genius either, at least not in his day to day life. I didn't find this book incredibly entertaining but it was informative.

I enjoyed this CD. The physics and math were hard to understand, but it was part of the whole story.  Wonderfully read and fun to listen to. If you have any love of science or want to understand the man and his time, it is very worth the time.

I think is isaacson had written my history books, or any dull material we are forced to read in school for that matter, I would have learned a lot more. As usual, well researched, laid-out, and written. Had no trouble really getting through it.

My first experience with Walter Isaacson was with his recent bio of Steve Jobs.  After reading the impressive and captivating Jobs bio, I decided to order his bios of Franklin and Einstein.  I wasn't disappointed.  Isaacson is a great writer.

I enjoyed learning more about Einstein. This a bit technical in nature, but shares the life of a very complex but compassionate man who truly believed in peace and love of your fellow man.  I would recommend listening to this to anyone.

This biography started well, and I found myself fascinated by Einstein's life. As it continued, however, the book became somewhat tedious and overly drawn out. Perhaps Einstein's later life was less interesting as well.
This biography reads like a story, creating suspense and other emotions that you experince while reading fiction. Einstein provides great insight into Einstein's mind and life. Highly recommended.

It's a great, honest look at what Albert as the scientist and Albert as the MAN.  There are a lot of fascintating facts I found out about him that I had no idea of before the read.  highly reccomended.

I do not typically write book reviews on Amazon but I felt compelled to after reading Einstein: His Life and Universe. I have always been somewhat intrigued by the man whose name has come to be synonymous with "genius" in modern culture. This book does a great job of balancing Einstein's personal life, his political/social philosophies, and--of course--the beauty of his science. Einstein without doubt was brilliant, but his true genius came from his ability to be innovative and creative, to form his own opinions despite tradition and doctrine.  It was a pleasure to explore the many facets and corners of Einstein's beautiful mind. There are some parts that can be more difficult for the reader to move through, like the chapter involving Einstein's search for a "Unified Field Theory" or "The Theory of Everything" that ultimately ended in vain. But these chapters are thrown in between much faster-paced ones about his own personal life and the times in which he lived. In many ways Einstein's biography is not just a story of his own life but a story of a time period in World History from the perspective of one of the most brilliant minds of the era. His personal story from the early 1900s in Europe through the worst of World War II and the birth of the Atomic Age in America make this biography an essential read.
Besides the history of Einstein, the Author can help us understand Einstein theory easier.  I believe this is quite a difficult task to achieve, but the author did it very well.
The writing is excellent. I thought  it was a bit too technical for me but I learned allot consequently. I was recommended to this and in turn will recommend it to others.
Found this book as complicated as Einstein himself.  Sometimes too technical, often times rambling although with such an amazing charactor worth pushing through the book.

Now that I'm done, I miss it.  Take the combined drama of the brilliant man, plus all his human qualities and frailties, and toss in the turmoil of his times as a Jewish uber-intellectual in 1920s-30s Europe, all served up with clear, specific, and easy to understand documented facts - it made my short bursts of downtime very enjoyable as I read a chapter or two at a time when I had a chance.  Isaacson presents a view into the soul of a great thinker and humanitarian, and although a nice man overall, at times he was a somewhat less than perfect husband, father, friend, or colleague, all backed up by clear, comprehensive research.  The emotional and spiritual quality of his struggle to complete and integrate quantum mechanics with our perceived reality is beautifully presented, as are the conflicts of his unstable family life, and the internal conflicts with his own unsteady faith and the social context of his time and place.  Read this and you won't have to be a math god to understand relativity, or a holocaust survivor to understand the power and failing of unchecked facism, or a struggling grad student to understand the value of real academic achievement and freedom of thought.
excellent biography.  cites little known facts;  gives a basic analysis of his work;  good inclusion of history, and its influence on his lifestyle decisions.

Many biographies try to recount a person's life through an entertaining and insightful narrative. Walter Isaacson does this, but also with an emphasis on the roots of Einstein's genius. Isaacson argues that there was nothing biologically unique about Einstein, but rather that Einstein's culture and personality shaped his genius. In particular, Isaacson believes Einstein's natural curiosity and rebellious nature allowed him to reach breakthrough insights. Overall, the book is well written and accessible even for readers with no background in physics. My only regret is, despite Isaacson's repeated claim that "Einstein's mistakes are more interesting than other people's successes," Isaacson never really explains Einstein's scientific mistakes. The first half of the book deals with Einstein's youth and physics theories, while the second half focuses almost exclusively on his politics. The second half barely even mentions his search for a unified field theory, much less try to explain his rationale. Instead, Isaacson retreads the claim that Einstein's latter years were wasted. Aside from this, it's a thoughtful look at the 20th century's greatest mind.

The size of this book may mislead you to think that this book maybe boring. But actually it is not. This biography of Einstein is my first "thickest" book I have ever read. As a slow reader, I was amazed how I read the book critically in a short period of time. The author of this book, Walter Isaacson writes Einstein's story in a captivating, provocative way the pushes the reader to believe that geniuses are not born but they are made. Einstein's story is so compelling. Isaacson starts with Einstein's childhood who had many problems including his inability to speak at an early age; then he delves into how he became a person that transform his imaginations to discover many physical entities that we enjoys today. Isaacson stated in this book that Einstein had a perfect blend of imagination and wisdom. After reading this book, I say, Einstein had a perfect blend of character, patience and tenacity to bring his imaginations into reality. If you are a person that is looking for inspiration as a young scientist and how to bring your imaginations of whatever it may be to reality, then you MUST read this book!
It is probably as well done as the subject matter allows. Nothing at all would be lost if it were half the size, but it is complete and interesting to read.

Walter Issacson provides a readable and thorough account of Einstien's life.  From his great scientific discoveries described in layman's terms (I have never taken a physics class in my life and easily understood the descriptions) to his personal life and what fame did to transform the way he lived.  The details are well laid out and prove once again Issacson's mastery of biography.  The theories that Issacson lay out are well thought out and provide insight into how Einstein came up with his ideas and conducted his famed thought experiments as the patent officer in Switzerland.  Einstein while undoubtedly brilliant was enthralled by being an underdog and by academia not accepting him initially he was able to look past their old ways and conceive something new.  The spare time at the patent office allowed him to conduct these experiments and provide theories that would shake theoretical physics to its core.  Overall it is highly readable and well worth the time for those looking for a non traditional history book or those in physics who want to learn more about the man behind the relativity.
From explanations of the complex science to the shaping of an intriguing human being, this biography has everything that will compel you to keep reading.

I am writing as someone who has taken classical/modern physics courses (though now years ago).  This Einstein biography is comprehensive in terms of his personal life and interactions with other physicists of the time (good sections on the various conferences).  It is also very thorough on Einstein's politics, which does significantly contribute to the overall picture of his life, as he was involved in many causes.  I would disagree with some reviewers, I felt like the overall flow of the book is consistent.  Probably the weakest point is its discussion of the physics itself.  This is the difficulty of a biography of someone like Einstein - include enough physics to make the biography complete, without turning into a physics text for PhDs.  I feel like the author undershot the mark on this a little bit and could have included a few more pages on discussion.  I found myself doing a lot of cross-referencing with physics books.  Nonetheless, it's a highly readable book and probably will be the life of Einstein book for years to come.

Walter Isaacson made a very good collection of data about Albert Einstein. The quantity and the quality of the information are very relevant and bring to the reader sense of reality of the facts. The biography is able to bring to the reader's mind the personality of such brilliant scientist as well as his connection with the scientific community and the interaction between the scientists of that time. The history background also contributes to a better understanding of Einstein's actions and contribution for society, in physics and politics. The impression given by the author, in my opinion, makes Einstein even better valorized by the reader. It is quite easy to identify the brilliant mind of Einstein and also his contribution for mankind, with his strengths (intelligence, criativity, goodness, sense of humor, etc...) and weaknesses (sometimes disagreeing based on old assumptions and closing his mind to new ideas). Balancing the facts, the results is unlimited positive). Walter Isaacson made a really an outstanding job.
This is a beautifully written book that draws the whole picture of Einstein's life , science, personal, and the politics of time. Exceptional.
I feel like I know Einstein know.  The author did a splendid job of bringing this important character into modern day.  what a joy to read.

In my younger reading days I thought the writings of Einstein biographer Banesh Hoffmann were the be all and end all of writing about Einstein.  Biography just couldn't get any better!  To me, it is the genre that can provide the ultimate thrill of personality!  It is quite possibly my favorite. So it is with considerable excitement that I share my impressions of Isaacson's "Einstein" as reaching the highest levels of his craft.  It means for me that in writing on his subject can be found all the components that are most effective in holding our attention, in exciting it!  A few that abound: illumination, profundity, affection and humor, grace through understanding, and of course exhaustive authoritative research and exploration.  I love this biography because it adds to Hoffmann's wonderful embrace of a man he loved and admired as a friend and colleague--because it too engages our hearts and minds in the thrill of personality. And in this case what a personality it was.
Biography and phisics, the life and the ideas of Einstein in their birth and development  are masterfully  analysed and outlined.
I was looking for a book that would tell me about Einstein the man without having to learn the math.  This book did this and more.
The book was interesting and well written. I learned things about Einstein that I was not aware of before the book.  Great read!

At the close of the 20th ecentury Time magazine proclaimed Albert Einstein to be "THe Man/Person of the Century."  This audio book will provide all the testimony that you may require to understand why Time made their proclamation.  It is the story of his life written and read in a journalistic yet personally touching style.  The book also serves as a very good introduction to his remarkable contributions to phyusics as well as his personal struggles and challenges that he dealt with through out his life.  His sory told in this way helps the reader/listener to relate personally with Einstein as a fellow human traveler.  The author did his research well.  While much of what Einstein brought to the world is both technical and abstract, we are able to clearly understand the entire narative.  My wife and I listened to this book in the car as we drove all day to a vacation point.  We were not disappointed.

I read Steve Jobs by Walter Isaacson, so I did not hesitate to send for this one about Einstein.  I am not quite finished, but I have really enjoyed this one also.  I can't add too much to the description, as prior reviewers have done a good job of that.  I can only add my approval.  Although, of course, I knew that Einstein was responsible for the theory of relativity and that he was indeed a genius, I was surprised to find that he was also a somewhat humble man who apparently did not think he was superior in most ways to others.  He did not seem to see any distinction between races and economical levels in the things that really counted.  I was somewhat surprised at the short and abrupt description of the illness and death of Einstein's wife, Elsa.  I would definitely recommend this book as well as the biography Mr. isaacson wrote of Steve Jobs.  Keep them coming!

I didn't want a review of his scientific work.  But I did want to know about his personal life.  I haven't finished the book.  I've jumped around reading highlights.  I have the feeling this book was painstakingly written for an accurate Einstein.  I was pleased to learn about his decisions and values.  His father was the owner of an electric power plant.  His father offered an engineering position that he didn't force on his son, Einstein.  If you read the book you will see what decisions he made, what kind of jobs he pursued and what he valued.  He is a role model for others because of his what he believed in.  I visited Bern Switzerland where he lived and sought citizenship in after he graduated college.  I stood in his home which is now a museum. They have many swiss army knife stores.  He wanted to do bicycle tours biweekly.  Such a beautifly country.

A wonderful biography of a unique, fascinating and enthralling person. The author brings freshness to this much-written subject by drawing on voluminous personal correspondence that remained sealed for 50 years following Einstein's death. The book is a remarkable achievement by being both highly readable and accessible, and providing scientifically sound explanations for the lay person of complex concepts of physics. As a history of science, of the early 20th century, and as a perspective on one of the most engaging and innovative personalities ever, this book is total education and refreshment. Especially moving is the fundamental thread of Einstein's personality as a lifelong quest for unifying principles, married to unsentimental devotion to reason, logic and a faith in the comprehensibility of the universe. (Good luck with that one.)

Isaacson assembles a biography with enough details to make a high school English student puke, but it creates a complete picture of one of the world's most famous scientists. Einstein's charisma is clearly illustrated in this text, from personal relationships to his obsessive pursuit to explain the universe. It took me 6 weeks to read partly because I'm a slow reader, partly because the book is heavy, but mostly because I enjoyed the ride. I'm no physics major but managed to comprehend many of Isaacson's presentations of Einstein's theories and thought experiments, most of which I've forgotten by now. By and far, it was most satisfying to look inside his personal life, how he married his cousin (you read that right), never wore socks, was truly absent-minded, and was still working on his theories on his deathbed.

A revelation to me of the man...  the whole man.  Details of his whole life, start to finish.  Chronicals his obsessions with unconceived science, concluding with his quest for a Unifying field theory.  Details his love life, his three children, his wives, and multiple lovers; quite the stud!!!  Alfred was anti war, for world government, for individual freedom in a disarmed world ruled by the armed enforcers.  He was so idealistic, softspoken kind, and posessed by his science.  He was instrumental in getting started on an A-bomb, but was kept out of the action by his detractors.  He made substantial efforts on behalf of the Hebrew University.  Hated by the anti-semitic, and leaving to become a patriotic American.

This is one of the best biographies of a scientist on the market. Isaacson had a mountain of material to work with but manages to put it into a highly readable and thoroughly enjoyable narrative. He gives the reader an excellent discussion of Einstein’s scientific work and a compelling portrait of the man, warts and all. It is a tough project to combine lucid writing with ideas like general relativity and quantum thought experiments but Isaacson succeeds. And, as in his biography of Franklin, Isaacson brings the subject of his biography to life. This is an engaging book, one that anyone interested in modern physics and the story of 20th century science would enjoy. A marvelous read. My highest recommendation.

I began reading this book the day I received it. I was particularly interested in the chapter: Einstein's God, p.384. The greatest value of the book is its reflection of Einstein's larger collection of his private papers, just released. Einstein was NOT an atheist; too much order and design in the universe to be an atheist. But, he did not believe in a personal God. I will be keeping this book by my side for years to come as a ready, authoritative reference to the life of this legendary man.

Unlike Darwin or Disney, Albert Einstein seemed to enjoy immensely the last chapters of his life, as well as all of those leading up to them.  Isaacson does a good job explaining why.  Einstein does not seem to have suffered the intense sense of inadequacy felt by many other great men, to his great fortune.  I liked the imagery of him sailing on Long Island Sound, becoming becalmed, and then relaxing with his note pad, doing calculations on the unified field theory, which was his crossword puzzle that would never be finished.  Isaacson's narrative moves along smoothly and cogently, though with undistinguished prose, including much new material from the recently opened archives, we are told.

Although when I first bought this book I put off reading it, intimidated by its length, once I ventured into it, it was smooth sailing. I could possibly write pages on Albert Einstein on my own respect, appreciation, and admiration of this man, but it would do no justice. Walter Isaacson did an excellent job on delivering the life of this wonderful man. It had, arguably, the right amount of Einstein's political, personal, and scientific insights. I shall continue on learning the simple nature of this complex man by reading more into each of his insights in detail by other distinguished authors, but for now, as a start, thank you Walter Isaacson for introducing me to my new superhero.
Best book available on the subject.  What more can I say that has not already been said?!

as an engineer i found the first half (??) of the book very interesting - but maybe too detailed for the non-technical reader.  altho isaacson is very good at reducing difficult concepts to plain english - there are some concepts that defy this translation.  the second half becomes a more personal story of the man and his ethic.  i found this half even more interesting as it dealt more with the man than with his scientific ideas.  altho i was aware of eistein's refusal to accept the package of concepts associated with quantum mechanics,  i was not aware that his struggle lasted a lifetime and occupied so much of his thoughts and work.  overall,  a good read.

This was one of the best written books I have ever read.  Kudo's to the author!  For a biography of a person we can all relate to, this read like a fiction thriller explaining the special and general theories of relativity and quantum physics for the laymen to understand, all rolled up in a perfectly sequenced novel explaining this great man's life from beginning to end and everything in between.  I couldn't wait to pick it up each day, and even though it was over a thousand pages long, I wished it could've gone on forever.  It was not only informative empirically but historically too.  A great read - I recommend it highly.

A well written and comprehensive look at Einstein's life. The author does a great job of telling of both the professional and personal development of Einstein. A bit more time spent on Einstein's physics theories than I would have preferred, but the letters and stories of his personal life are shared in such a way that you get a good sense of his personality and how he developed his beliefs and causes throughout his life. The author shares both the positive and not so positive aspects of the man. I very much enjoyed this biography.

I felt compelled to write this review because this is one of the few books that I have immensely enjoyed and learned from. It is a fascinating work about Einstein and his life, packed with brilliant quotes and stories. Isaacson has done a thorough job with the amount of detail he included. Einstein's life was truly interesting, and in addition, the author has done a superb job in raising the interest level. Reading the book often made me chuckle, and once brought tears. I feel that Einstein was accurately portrayed, as the great person that he was. Thank You Walter Isaacson, for this great book.

A complete work but the most important feature of this book is the clarity  Isaacson achieves by painstakingly explaining the workings and scientific significance of special and general relativity.  Einstein was accessible yet infinitely enigmatic, and the author takes special care to explain why that was, and why the icon we refer to as Einstein still somehow manages to be so elusive.  After reading this book, you will truly appreciate how monumental and complex a figure Einstein really was.  Isaacson's already classic biography belongs in everyone's library.

This biography of Einstein life was a great introduction into the scientific process and into Einstein's discoveries. I enjoy the mix of gossip about his life and the science that he was preforming along the way. Einstein's Relativity work was explains in a way to not go into to much detail, but left the reader with a good understanding. I found that this explanation of Relativity allowed me to understand it a little more and gave me the desire to research it more outside the book.  I would recommend this book to anyone interested in science most in physics.

Einstein's fame has ensured the knowledge of what he was to some extent among common people. This book presents so many details in consistent development to give us the right perspective. We can identify with Einstein for all his failings and weakness too. That is not to say his glory as physicist is toned down in this biography. Also, how well he was grounded in social justice, while facing the challenges and opposition comes out nicely. On the whole we can and should relate to Einstein without awe. He was like one of us. This book certainly helps in appreciating that.

Well written and engaging.  The writer seems very fluent in scientific theory.  While some of the science was hard (for me) to follow (we're talking about one of the greatest theoretical minds in history in Einstein, of course), for the most part explanations were made in layman's terms.  Covered a fair amount of Einstein's personal life, which created a sense of curiosity and caring about the man behind the science.  I read (listened to) it to gain a better understanding of science and a famous scientific figure ... and I was well satisfied.

An introspective biography of arguably one of the best well known scientific icons of the 20th century. Walter Isaacson gives a detailed historic overview of Einstein's upbringing, family life, and his scientific, social, and political endeavors. While I can't vouch for the accuracy of the authors scientific interpretations, Walter Isaacson goes to great lengths to explain Einstein's theories and to place them in their proper historical context - how they were developed, why, and what are the impacts. Overall, a great and a rewarding read.

As an aspiring biological scientist and a serious physics-dork, this was a fascinating book.  How Einstein thought, related to others, and the trajectory of his career I've seen microscopically mirrored in my mentors and colleagues.  What I found most amazing is that the atmosphere of science 100 years ago, with the rival hypotheses and personal encroachments into an objective world still exists today; I'm coming to believe is a universal part of research.  Isaacson captured all of this in this tremendous biography.

Reading a book by Isaacson is like having a comfortable conversation with an articulate and knowledgeable friend.  You discover things you never knew or understood before, painlessly.  He is not afraid to acknowledge when he disagrees with prevailing wisdom, and allows you to make up your own mind on the subject.  Einstein comes to life in this book as he has never done before.  He is every bit as lovable, but a great deal less naive than he has been portrayed in other books.  And far more interesting.

Walter Isaacson has clearly covered the bases in researching one of the most fascinating and brilliant human beings ever born, but I often got lost in the "nitty gritty" details that at times seemed trivial in fleshing out Einstein's genius.  I do recommend this book to anyone interested in Einstein's thoughts, his life and how he became one of the most relevant minds in history to date, but I feel Isaacson could have gotten his point across with fewer words and a little more passion about his subject.

In addition to providing much useful information about EInstein's upbringing, education and private life, the book includes valuable insights into the thought processes that led to  EInstein's amazing and unique scientific discoveries. The author  discusses the physics underlying Einstein's insights in a lucid manner that is completely understandable to the average reader. Anyone interested in understanding the context and conditions that led to Einstein's remarkable achievements will enjoy this book.

Einstein: His Life and Universe by Walter Isaacson is an absolutely fascinating read for anyone interested in the history of modern Physics and one of its most enigmatic icons. The book simultaneously weaves in Einstein's personal life, his struggles both on personal level and also his struggle to be accepted as a theoretical physicist, and all this against the backdrop of the two world wars. Beautifully written but only meant for those who are fascinated by the history of modern physics.

This is a fascinating book that finely balances the details of Einstein's life along with compelling and comprehensible accounting of Einstein's ideas.  This is no easy feat because Einstein's ideas are very difficult to understand.  But I truly appreciated that this wasn't simply a book about Einstein the man, but the ideas he presented to the world.  Having said that, this book paints a vivid and entertaining biography of a fascinating man that is worth the price of admission alone.

This book was a very interesting read. I found the details of Einstein's life fascinating, especially all of the aspects of his personal life. The book got a little too "into the weeds" on technical discussions of physics, but that was the core of Einstein so it's difficult to write such a thorough book and not have that level of detail on the science. I have thoroughly enjoyed this author's works (I read the Steve Jobs bio as well) and plan to read other books he's written.

This is a thorough biography of Einstein. Being thorough, it goes into his disagreements with other scientists and explains the differences that they had, which means discussing the theories of physics over the years.  At times, trying to follow the "discussions" took a lot of thought for this simple mind, but the author did a good job of explaining them so that even I could eventually follow them.  It was enjoyable reading but I had to take my time to let thought processes sink in.

I've read two biographies of Einstein, and Isaacson's is much better than Clark's, which was published in 1971.  Not only does Isaacson offer a clear portrait of the man himself, but his presentation of Einstein's chief ideas is exceptionally clear.  In fact, he presents those ideas for a popular audience more clearly than Einstein did in the book he wrote with Leopold Infeld, THE EVOLUTION OF PHYSICS.  This work is an outstanding accomplishment.

You don't have to be proficient in the sciences to enjoy this book. Isaacson writes clearly and he obviously put a lot of research into the text. Albert Einstein and his parents led interesting lives. There are several nuggets of interest I was not aware of until I read the first few chapters- among the most prominent were Einstein's gift for playing the violin and his father with uncle Jacob running one of the first electrical companies.

This was an extremely difficult biography to write, since so much of the meaningful information was so complex. It was impossible to comfortably understand a good bit of it. Nevertheless, the book provides enough explanation to enhance anyone'e understanding of physics and its patron saint, Einstein. There are also many interesting stories of human interest. I believe Einstein himself would be proud of this effort to describe his work.

While a scientific background is helpful to fully appreciate Einstein's academic struggles and breakthroughs, the book is not meant to explain the theory of special relativity or quantum entanglement (though it does try). Isaacson references Einstein's own letters, speeches, and notes to show the transformation from a man with deeply troubled personal and academic lives to the most remarkable and revered scientists of our time.

I enjoyed this immensely, but found myself wishing that I had gotten the unabridged version. The narrative would cut off before fully covering the topic at hand, and sometimes I would find myself deep into a subject that needed more introduction. I am sure the full version would have avoided these issues. Otherwise, it was an intriguing story -- so much so that I ordered the printed version to allow me to get the whole story.

Isaacson is a master biographer.  His research seems to be impeccable, and he leaves one with a great feel for the man.  He may have won the Pulitzer Prize for this, but it is nowhere near his best.  Steve Jobs is a far more compelling bio; I'm not a fan of Jobs, and I am of Einstein, but Jobs may just be a more interesting personality for a biographer to work with.  It's worth reading, but not in the top ten bios I've read.

No single book or author can hope to fully and impartially describe a person, especially one as complex as Einstein, but I think Isaacson gives it a pretty good shot. I don't feel like important parts were left out or that I need to read some other Einstein biography to get a balanced view. This book was comprehensive and seemed fair, and other than verging a little bit toward the academic, was a very smooth read.

Good book on Einstein viewed as a man, reading what his entire life was like, that it wasn't always a bowl of cherries for the Professor.  I enjoyed this book, mostly enjoyed the portion of the book about his adult life, and some of the oddities of his life that made the professor so unusual and interesting.  I would have loved to have met the man in person, but reading about him is about as good as it will get.

This is one of the most facinating biographies I have ever read. I, being fourteen, found myself sometimes a bit overwhelmed with the math and physics. But I will say that when the author explains it, it is easier to comprehend. I would recomend this book to ANYONE who wants a thurough (I being no Einstein myself know that is spelled wrong) and epic look at the personal life and triumphs of this genius.

This is one of the best biographies I've ever read. The author not only explores Einstein's scientific accomplishments, but delves into his personal life and history as well. He uses previously unreleased sources to explore Albert's personal side. Whether you're familiar with Einstein's scientific achievements or not, you'll enjoy exploring the development of one of the greatest minds of the modern era.

I already read this book. This one is a gift. If you've heard rumors stories or are just curious about one of the greatest geniuses that walked this earth get this book. Find out facts you may have never known or straighten up false stories passed on. All firsthand information with a Bibliography that is nearly as long as the book itself. I'll probably get another copy later to keep it in my library.

Master Biographer, Walter Isaacson did a superb job writing this inspiring and engaging biography of Einstein.  Isaacson gives great insight into Einstein's mind. He also does a great job explaining the physics behind Einstein's inventions. Perhaps his greatest achievement is his ability to convey Einstein's spirit and sense of humor.  "Einstein: His Life and Universe" is a true delight to read.

There is one thing about Einstein's life that unfortunately the author doesn't explore.  Einstein was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm in 1948.  In 1951 in the AMA Archives of Surgery, a French doctor reported the first repair of this condition with a graft to replace the defective area of the aorta.  Why was  Einstein not given the chance to have this operation?  He died in 1955.

This is probably the best book that I have ever read. It literally changed my life and hoisted Albert Einstein way up high as my favourite person in history. Walter Isaacson has written a peerless biography but this book is way so much more than that. It is also a compelling history of science, and for me, resolved the last unknowables about the human existenstial condition.

This book gives a much broader impression of the character of Einstein and his works.  He comes across as a combination of both warm and indifferent in his relationships with others.  He clearly seems better able to foster intellectual friendships than personal or family ones.  The author is very adept in describing in summary fashion Einstein's scientific works.

Well written, but no matter how you shake it up - physics is a dry subject.  And Einstein's life, after all, was all about physics.  For that reason, this book does not fall into the "page turner" category - at least for me.  Nonetheless, Walter Isaacson can take even a dry subject like this and make it interesting - the reason for the four star rating.

This was an excellent, interesting and very readable biography, but what impressed me most was the clear explanations of the breakthroughs in physics that Einstein made. Over the years I've read various attempts to explain some of these difficult ideas, but this book made so much clear to me that I'd recommend some sections be quoted in physics textbooks!

Very good read.  I believe that if Einstein were to walk into a room, I would have something to say to him.  There were some dry points in this book, but that is only because Einstein was so deep.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it and believe Walter Isaacson has a gift in his approach.  Very good read, highly recommended for those who like the biography.

One of the best books.  The author takes us very close to a Great Scientist !  He narrates in his own beautiful style, Einstein's Fucus on exploring the Relativity Theory right from his school days till his last day on this planet !  Einstein has withstood many  any family problems (might be of his own creations) and faced political struggles and even threats to his life.  But his focus on his exploration of the ever expanding universe, never got distracted, unmindful of his own even health problems.  A must for every book lover.

While I have not finished reading it yet I am very impressed with the detail both biographical and relating to Einstein's genius and his thought processes - this includes many of the revolutionary ideas of his theories in the context of other ideas of physics at the times of these developments.

A well written, informative and quite comprehensive biography.  I needed to read some of the chapters describing scientific concepts slowly and carefully in order to fully understand and retain the ideas. This may be more a reflection of my incapacity than weaknesses in the writing.  Definitely recommended to anyone interested in Einstein's life and work.
Great reading interesting and very well written. Good not stop reading. Lots of new informations about his life and mentality

Isaacson has brought out all the intrigue and characters associated with Einstein's life and career. Very thorough and easy to read, though may require some understanding of science theory. Would recommend it.

This depicts exceptionally well the life of the person and his time, his colleagues and the tormented world history. and on the fly teaches relativity theory to non-experts in a way which should be fathomable for someone with an high-school education.

Fantastic book. Full of anecdotes as well as very easy to understand relativity principles seen from Einsteins' perspective. Very inspirational book about one of the greatest minds. Thoroughly enjoyed reading it.
Excellent writing. Well researched. Complex scientific concepts made accesible to lay readers. I heard it first in Audible and enjoyed it.

This is a book to read for the future generations who have only know Einstein for his brain. This is one to understand and remember a man who had a heart as beautiful as his brilliant mind. It is important to remember him for all that he was and not just for his contribution to physics. Walter Isaacson has captured the emotions perfectly.
Brilliant in depth writing giving you an understanding of this complex man. Arguably the greatest brain in the history of mankind.
Extremely well written. Exhaustive as it can get. Story telling style, which makes it engrossing and gripping. A must read.
Very good for people who have any interest in science. It made me read related material . Very interesting scientifically and socially.

The thought of reading about the great Einstein never occurred to me. The only reason that I bought this book, was Walter Isaacson. And I wasn't disappointed. I had recently read his work on Steve Jobs, and his writing style, profound command of the English language and his impeccable research, turned me into a raving fan. This book confirmed my initial views of Mr. Isaacson. He has dealt with arguably the greatest mind ever to have lived, in a respectful, yet easy to read manner. This detailed work not only discussed Einstein's personal life and character, but also looked at his academic life and showed the great complexity of his quests in a way that was eminently readable. Not only is the book researched incredibly well (see the vast list of persons that the author interviewed and/or asked to review portions of the manuscript - including the top experts in their fields to ensure that the theories/discoveries were accurately represented), it is told as a very personal story of another human being warts and all.  I discovered Einstein's sense of humor, especially with the Olympia Society that he and two lifelong friends created to mock the stuffy academic societies.  Einstein notes that after later being recruited by several of these societies, he and his friends were right on the mark.  Even the Time Magazine Person of the Century is just like you and me, and I admire him all the more because I now know the man.  And, I don't want to leave out the fact that Walter Isaacson takes you through Einstein's development of his theories - what triggered them in his head, the thought pictures that he used to work them out, and the events of his life that looked like they would stifle him - settling for being a Swiss Patent Examiner - that actually gave him the time and freedom of thought to work things out.  Finally, I enjoyed having the theories of General Relativity and Special Relativity presented in descriptive language I could understand, though certainly not in a condescending manner.  I don't do physics and wouldn't have thought about buying this book (or any book for about 10 more years), so I am pleased to have had the good luck to have it fall in my lap.  Thank you Mr. Isaacson.

Albert Einstein - "Locksmith of the mysteries of the atom and the universe" - yes, indeed. It took me about a month to listen to all the 18 discs while driving to and from work, and at the end I felt an emotional separation from the writings of Walter Issacson -  a great writer with a sophisticated flare. Albert Einstein was a genius who defied dogmas, and rebelled against authorities, conventional wisdom and conformism.  Through his creativity and  intellect he gave the world  the postulates of the Theory of Relativity - many thought it as a radical concept at that time. Theory of Relativity was the greatest leap by mankind towards understanding the mysteries of the universe through relative motion, simultaneity, time dilation, length contraction and energy-mass equivalence, these are incomprehensible harmonious concepts. Time dilation led to the theoretical possibility of time travel and energy-mass equivalence (or e=mc2) led to the creation of atom-bomb, to which Einstein lamented. Einstein in no way participated in creation of the bomb, but had hand in the in pushing the US government to consider the creation of the bomb. With all his contributions that lead to the understanding of the universe, Einstein never received Nobel Prize for Theory of Relativity, but instead he received for his work in photoelectric effect (read the book for the politics behind this). He was a pacifist at early stages of his life, but gave up pacifism when he understood the threat posed by Nazis. Einstein was a socialist democrat, who believed in continual progression and restrained capitalism, and promoted world federalism throughout his life. He struggled to find tranquility in his personal life, his personal life was a roller-coaster ride from start to finish. My only critique of Einstein is his rejection of Neils Bohr's theory on the movement of electrons. Einstein rejected this idea by saying "God does not play dice". He did not believe in randomness, he believed that every action in the universe is governed by laws and patterns. Did Einstein become a conformist? Since EHLU is the only Einstein biography I've ever read, I'm not sure whether it adds to the vast existing literature on Einstein.  Even if it adds little, however, it strikes me as an excellent biography to read if one intends to read only one Einstein biography.  WI does a superb job of describing Einstein the scientist and Einstein the man, and gives admirable account of Einstein's very abstruse scientific theories and discoveries.  In only one respect did I find EHLU disappointing: WI hews closely to his subject -- Einstein -- but touches only tangentially, in general, on Einstein's world.  World wars, the rise and fall of nations, etc., emerge only indistinctly from the pages of EHLU.  Of course, greater depth would have required a much longer treatment.  I, for one, would have been happy to read on, but I respect the strategy WI pursued in telling Einstein's story.  And what a story it is.  Einstein, genius, flaws, and all, will never cease to fascinate and inspire.  WI's account is honest and engaging.  It is also -- how could it be otherwise? -- reverent.  A terrific biography.

Many biographies have been written on Einstein's life. This is one of the better ones.It is relatively long and very comprehensive; furthermore, it is easy and delightful to read. It is, perhaps, best compared to Albert Folsing's definitive work "Albert Einstein." Isaacson covers much of the same material, but his book appears to be more directed at a popular audience, in that he uses quotes extensively. Some of the more interesting features of the book are Einstein's struggle with his unified field theory, a discussion of his concept of God, his disdain for the philosophical implications of quantum mechanics, and his ideas on peace. The last chapter deals with Einstein's brain: what happened to it and how it compares to other brains. There is a large section of black and white photographs in the center, and a long section of notes at the end. All in all it is an excellent addition to the library of books on Einstein.
